Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Noncovalently Bound Molecular Trimers: High-dimensional and Fully Coupled Quantum Calculations of their Vibrational Levels
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacic (NYU) and Felker (UCLA) are supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop and implement a novel and powerful methodology for accurate high-dimensional and fully coupled quantum calculations of the vibrational eigenstates of hydrogen-bonded and van der Waals molecular trimers. They will focus on realistic molecular complexes of considerable practical and fundamental importance and amenable to spectroscopic investigations, allowing for direct comparison between theory and experiment. Their studies will lead to more accurate description of the noncovalent intermolecular interactions, which play a major role in bulk liquids, molecular solids, and atmospheric chemistry, and the processes that occur in these environments. Bacic and Felker will continue to foster inclusivity by mentoring diverse and gender-balanced groups of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers. They will engage in a variety of outreach activities, including popular science presentations, to underrepresented high-school minority students.

Bacic and Felker will introduce a general approach that will enable, for the first time, high-dimensional fully coupled quantum calculations of the vibrational levels of noncovalently bound molecular trimers, for either flexible or rigid monomers. They will develop rigorous quantum bound-state methodologies aimed at the following three classes of paradigmatic hydrogen-bonded molecular trimers. (1) Trimers of flexible diatomic molecules, e.g., (HF)3 and (HCl)3, in 12D. (2) Trimers of rigid small polyatomic molecules, e.g., (H2O)3, in 12D. (3) Two types of mixed trimers of rigid molecules, exemplified by (HCl)(H2O)2 and the halide dihydrate complexes X-(H2O)2 (X = Cl, Br, I), in 11D and 9D, respectively. Through comparison between the computed vibrational levels and the transitions observed in the infrared (IR) spectra of the trimers, they will assess the accuracy of the ab initio calculated nonadditive three-body interactions incorporated in the trimer potential energy surfaces (PESs). Moreover, such a comparison will help them greatly with the assignment of the measured IR spectra, which for fluxional complexes is heavily reliant on theory. The intermolecular PESs of many molecular trimers, e.g., (H2O)3 and X-(H2O)2 (X = Cl, Br, I), exhibit multiple low-barrier tunneling pathways connecting the degenerate minima, which give rise to intricate patterns of tunneling splittings, observable in the measured spectra. The fully coupled quantum calculations by Bacic and Felker of the intermolecular vibrational states of the trimers will for the first time yield the tunneling splittings in the excited vibrational states.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have successfully developed the methodology for the computing, in full dimensionality (12D), the vibrational states of weakly bound trimers consisting of diatomic monomers (given access to an intermolecular potential-energy surface - IPES). We have applied that methodology to two paradigmatic hydrogen-bonded trimers: HF trimer and HCl trimer and have compared the results to experiment. Such studies are essential in order to (1) assess the quality of computed IPESs and (2) help interpret experimental results.
We have also developed the only existing methodology for the calculation of intermolecular vibrational states in perhaps the most important trimer species - water trimer. This 12D problem is extremely challenging as the species effectively samples 48 equivalent IPES minima and the vibrational degrees of freedom are large-amplitude and very strongly coupled. Our methodology breaks the 12D problem up into a 9D "bend" computation and a 3D "frame" computation. We have just recently (September 2024) published our first paper on the "bend" problem, a work largely focused on methodology. Two other papers are currently being written up: (1) A detailed analysis of the nature of the computed "bend" states, and (2) A work describing the methodology and the results of the full "frame" plus "bend" calculations. The further computational work on water trimer, and other water clusters, that these studies have made possible is copious: mixed trimer isotopomers, calculations of rotational level structures, extensions to larger water clusters, and extensions to water-solvated ion clusters. We anticipate being actively engaged in these extensions for at least the next several years.
We have also completed a computational study of the intermolecular vibrational states and rotational level structure of a hydrogen-bonded dimer of considerable interest in atmospheric chemistry and astronomy: water-HCN. In that study we made use of a newly computed potential-energy surface and performed the calculations assuming rigid monomers. We anticipate that the results will be especially useful in modeling important processes in the earth's atmosphere and in outer space.
We have also computed the intermolecular states and rotational level structure of a second water-containing dimer of atmospheric interest, water-CO2, in the rigid-monomer approximation. As with water-HCN we expect these results to be of some use to those modeling the chemistry and physics of the earth's atmosphere. 
Going beyond the rigid-monomer approximation we have developed and applied the methodology to compute the vibrational states of water-diatom dimers in full dimensionality. We are the first to have done this. For this project we applied this protocol to the important hydrogen-bonded dimer water-HCl. Our computed results, obtained for an IPES newly computed by Prof. Jun Li's group, were compared to spectroscopic results in the literature.
Finally, we have developed and applied the methodology to compute inelastic neutron scattering (INS) spectra of endohedral molecules in fullerene cages. INS studies of such species are becoming increasingly common and constitute important sources of information on this class of endohedral complexes. The ability to simulate such spectra from rigorous calculations of the vibrational states of the endohedral complexes is a significant aid to the interpretation of the experimental results.
